newsitem.title: UK: Adams calls on Dublin to monitor N.Irish parades.
newsitem.headline: Adams calls on Dublin to monitor N.Irish parades.

text.p: Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams urged Dublin on Wednesday to send observers to British Northern Ireland during volatile Protestant marches in a bid to ease anxiety among minority Catholics.

Adams, whose party is the political arm of banned Irish Republican Army (IRA) guerrillas, condemned the province's chief pro-British Protestant leader, David Trimble, for saying Protestants should be allowed to parade past Catholic homes next July.

"It is very important that beleagured communities have some sense that ...there is someone trying to assist them during these difficult time," Adams said after talks with Catholics in a south Belfast zone that is a sectarian flashpoint during annual summer parades by Protestants.

Adams said Ireland, to whom the province's Catholics owe allegiance, should "agree to send monitors during marches who will scrutinise developments...and provide some assurance for local communities that their fears and concerns are being acknowledged."
His remarks came 24 hours after Britain said parade organisers must give police three weeks' notice of intended parades instead of the current one week.
It also said police would be empowered to confiscate alcohol, often blamed as a key factor in confrontations.

Last weekend Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, said members of the Protestant Orange Order, of which he is a member, should be allowed to hold a march through a Catholic district of Portadown, southwest of Belfast, at the height of the Order's "marching season".
Adams branded Trimble's remarks to an American magazine as "totally unacceptable".
A similar march at Portadown last year lit a fuse for the province's worst sectarian disturbances for many years.
Protestants, backed by streets protests and road blocks, had a furious three-day standoff with riot police until senior officers reversed a decision and allowed them to parade through the district.
Gangs of Catholic youths hurled hundreds of petrol bombs at police in Londonderry and other areas. Two people died and many were injured.

Politicians across the province, already pessimistic because of a fresh eruption of IRA violence, fear a repetition of marching season disturbances that would deal another blow to the region's crippled peace drive.
The IRA, drawing support among some Catholics, is fighting to end British rule of Northern Ireland.

Protestants regard their annual marches as a cornerstone of a public reaffirmation of loyalty to their religion and to the British Crown. They say Catholics want to deny them their right to be British.
Catholics regard the often boisterous Protestant marches as displays of triumphalism, commemorating ancient victories over the native Irish.
